Key Arguments: The Universal Declaration of Human Rights (UDHR) emphasizes the inherent dignity and equal rights of all human beings.
It highlights the importance of freedom of speech, belief, and protection from fear and want.
The UDHR underscores the necessity of protecting human rights through the rule of law to prevent tyranny and oppression.
It calls for the promotion of friendly relations between nations and the universal respect for human rights.
The Declaration outlines specific rights such as the right to life, liberty, security, freedom from slavery, torture, and arbitrary arrest.

It includes rights to fair trial, privacy, freedom of movement, asylum, nationality, marriage, property, thought, opinion, expression, assembly, participation in government, social security, work, rest, education, and cultural life.
The UDHR stresses the importance of duties to the community and the limitations of rights to ensure respect for others' rights and public order.
Main Themes: Comprehensive list of civil, political, economic, social, and cultural rights
Balance between individual rights and community duties
Notable Quotes: All human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights.

Everyone has the right to freedom of opinion and expression; this right includes freedom to hold opinions without interference and to seek, receive and impart information and ideas through any media and regardless of frontiers.
Everyone has duties to the community in which alone the free and full development of his personality is possible.
